In order to exceed 80,000 deliveries in 2016 Tesla only needs to exceed its 2nd half guidance of 50,000 cars by 3,210. That implies Q4 deliveries of 28,710, which would be an increase of about 17% from Q3. In light of recent production and delivery growth trends that seems achievable. Tesla has undershot its guidance on a YTD 2016 basis, and in order to maintain credibility it is likely that the company is sandbagging its 2nd half guidance of 50,000 deliveries. Bottom line, I see better than even odds that Tesla will deliver more than 80,000 cars for the full year.

Tesla eliminated two color choices. Why? Perhaps it is due to production problems or no demand for the colors. The popularity of the color white (one of the discontinued colors) on cars makes low demand unlikely. Now black is the only no-additional-cost color you can order from Tesla which will result in overall higher prices for a Tesla. At any rate, whatever the reason(s) this is more likely to hurt sales rather than help them. Additionally, Tesla has just dropped the entry-level model X as an option for purchase. Once again, why? Production problems or lack of demand? Either way, fewer colors and fewer cars to choose from = fewer sales overall. My forecast is therefore revised down to 10% from 11%.

If you add planned production increases it gives them a little more of a margin of error, but not much.
